Python Session 2 — Python Basics

Syntax, variables, conditionals, loops, data structures

Juan F. Imbet

Paris Dauphine University-PSL

Why Python?

  • General‑purpose, batteries included, huge ecosystem
  • Readable like English; great for rapid prototyping

Running Python

  • REPL: python
  • Scripts: python file.py
  • Notebooks: Jupyter/VS Code

Hello, world

print("Hello, world")

Variables and types

x = 42          # int
pi = 3.14       # float
name = "Ana"    # str
ok = True       # bool
  • Dynamic typing; type(x) tells you the runtime type

Strings

msg = f"Hi {name}!"
msg.upper()
  • Slicing, methods, f-strings for formatting

Lists (ordered, mutable)

nums = [1, 2, 3]
nums.append(4)
nums[0] = 10

Tuples (ordered, immutable)

point = (3, 4)
  • Useful for fixed records, dictionary keys

Sets (unique, unordered)

ids = {1, 2, 2, 3}  # {1, 2, 3}
  • Fast membership tests

Dicts (key → value)

user = {"id": 1, "name": "Ana"}
user["email"] = "ana@example.com"

Conditionals

if x > 0:
    print("positive")
elif x == 0:
    print("zero")
else:
    print("negative")

Loops: while

i = 0
while i < 3:
    print(i)
    i += 1

Loops: for

for n in [1, 2, 3]:
    print(n)
  • Iterates over any iterable

Range and enumerate

for i, n in enumerate(range(5, 8)):
    print(i, n)

Comprehensions

squares = [n*n for n in range(10)]
  • Read as: build a list by repeating a pattern

Functions

def area(r: float) -> float:
    return 3.1416 * r * r
  • Optional type hints aid readability

Exceptions

try:
    1 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError as e:
    print("oops", e)

Modules and imports

import math
from pathlib import Path

File I/O

with open("notes.txt", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write("hello\n")

Lambdas and itertools (bonus)

from itertools import accumulate, chain
double = lambda x: 2*x
list(accumulate([1,2,3]))  # [1, 3, 6]
list(chain([1,2], [3,4]))  # [1,2,3,4]

Idioms

  • EAFP: Easier to Ask Forgiveness than Permission
  • Truthy/Falsey values

Exercise 1

  • Read a CSV, count lines, print first 5

Exercise 2

  • Build a frequency dict for words in a text

Wrap‑up

  • You can write basic Python with core data structures and control flow
  • Next: OOP and types

Slicing

nums = [0,1,2,3,4]
nums[1:4], nums[:3], nums[::2]

Unpacking

a, b = 1, 2
x, *rest = [10, 20, 30]

Truthiness

  • empty list/dict/set → False; non‑empty → True

Ternary expression

label = "even" if x % 2 == 0 else "odd"

with context manager

from contextlib import suppress
with suppress(FileNotFoundError):
    open("maybe.txt").read()

Small gotchas

  • Mutable default args; indentation errors

Knowledge check (quiz)

  • List vs tuple difference?
  • What does enumerate do?

Intro to VBA and Python
